(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. H. Henry
Address: Macassar, P.R.M.
Birthplace: Saltashville, Ontario.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1881
Where did you set up housekeeping? Crystal City, Montana

For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 10 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Just when necessary
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Groceries, we didn't drink tea so I found done the first year.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back or page if more space is needed].

We rarely always bought our groceries in quantities during our homestead days in Manitoba coming there in 1881 in March. I had to drive 150 miles from the station at Emerson to our home at Crystal City. In 1902 we moved with our family of 6 children having lost 1 son 2 years before not quite 10 years ago to Cunningham Manor, M.W.S. (there) Sask., I had 1 son after, my husband died in 1908, but my sons and family carried on with farming etc., but around 20 years ago I took over the farm & now at the age of 90 years, I am not able to do much & worst trouble cannot see to read, sew, write etc., so live with my children as most of them are settled.

Through the years the prices have been much the same at times very expensive & other times very very cheap, but we always managed. So hard to quote prices on groceries etc.

Some years when first married we had our own flour made from our wheat, also after coming to Sack, was a flour mill at old Cannington Manor & later one at Arcola & we got flour, graham flour & grits for porridge & we nearly always in the winter ground our wheat for porridge & we generally bought a year's supply of flour.
